title: Blencathra Circular Walk Route

images.title: K  A / Blencathra
images.caption: Blencathra's summit as from the ascent via Scales Fell. The dip in the summit ridge, that led to the Fell's alternative name of Saddleback, is well seen from here

images.title: Martyn Ayre / Sharp Edge, Blencathra
images.caption: Sharp Edge, Blencathra. The patch of dirty snow marks the top of what the Mountain Rescue Team call "The Usual Gully".

images.title: Andrew Smith / Gategill Fell, Blencathra
images.caption: Gategill Fell, Blencathra. Looking across from the lower part of Halls Fell. The view comprises the fells around Derwentwater and Newlands.

images.title: Andrew Smith / Halls Fell, Blencathra
images.caption: Halls Fell. Looking down into Doddick Gill and onto the Doddick Fell, another of Blencathra's ridges. Great Mell Fell can be seen across the valley.

images.title: Ian Taylor / Skiddaw from Blencathra
images.caption: Skiddaw from Blencathra. Looking westwards from near the summit. The fells are (from the left) Lonscale Fell (NY2827), Little Man (NY2627) and Skiddaw (NY2629). They are now almost free of snow as this shot was taken in late March 2010. The enclosures in the Glenderaterra valley (NY2927 & 2928) can be seen in the middle distance.

images.title: Philip Halling / Blencathra Ridge
images.caption: View of the Blencathra ridge and the summit from sub-summit (851m) between Knowe Crags and Hallsfell Top

description: This is a fantastic climb to the summit of one of the Lake District's most well known and popular mountains. The walk begins at the parking lot in the pretty village of Threlkeld. You then climb Blencathra (or Saddleback) via Scales Fell, Scales Tarn and Sharp Edge. Sharp Edge is a challenging scramble along a narrow crest. Alfred Wainright describes it thus: 'The crest itself is sharp enough for shaving (the former name was razor edge) and can be traversed only a cheval at some risk of damage to tender parts.' From the summit there are fabulous views of the mountains of Galloway, the Southern Uplands, the Border hills, the Cheviots, the Pennines and North Wales.  Derwent Water and Thirlmere lakes are also visible. The walk descends to Knowe Crags and Blease Farm before returning to Threlkeld. For a shorter/easier walk to the summit please see the Blencathra Easy Route page. This starts from the elevated car park at the Blencathra Field Studies Centre, cutting out some of the ascent.
